summary: Israeli military operations are escalating in Rafah, Gaza, with Israeli forces seizing the Rafah border crossing on Tuesday, which was a main entry point for aid, thereby dashing ceasefire hopes[27]. This seizure, along with the closure of the Kerem Shalom crossing, has halted the entry of fuel and aid into Gaza, creating a disastrous situation for humanitarian response and depleting critical supplies[30]. Israel has issued evacuation orders for parts of Rafah, causing chaos and panic among the population, with over 150,000 people having fled in recent days and around 300,000 affected by the orders[19]. Vulnerable individuals, including malnourished infants and injured patients, are among those forced to move to already overcrowded and unsafe areas like Al-Mawasi and Khan Younis, which lack adequate shelter and humanitarian supplies[19]. UN officials and humanitarian partners warn that these operations will lead to more death, displacement, and a humanitarian catastrophe, emphasizing that there are no safe spaces in Gaza[17]. Meanwhile, ceasefire talks are stalled, as Hamas accepted a proposal that Israel deemed unacceptable, particularly regarding a permanent end to hostilities[7], and violations against Palestinians in the occupied West Bank have also substantially increased[12].

SDG 1 - No Poverty.question: How does the UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk view the Israeli orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, and what are the anticipated humanitarian consequences?
SDG 1 - No Poverty.retrieved_answer:
The UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk warned that Israel's orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, ahead of an anticipated new offensive, would cause civilian deaths, suffering, and destruction to increase beyond already unbearable levels [1]. He stated that Gazans are already being affected by bombs, disease, and famine, and are now being told to relocate again as Israeli military operations in Rafah escalate [1]. Türk views these orders as contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which prioritize the effective protection of civilians [1].

He also stated that Palestinians remaining in Rafah would continue to be at risk of death and injury from indiscriminate bombing, unlawful killing, or loss of access to food, water, and healthcare [2]. Türk emphasized that this situation "must not be allowed to happen" and that those who choose to disregard international humanitarian law and international human rights law must be held accountable [2].

1.context: title: IsraelOccupied Palestinian Territory: Rafah threat is inhumane, says UN Human Rights Chief ENAR  content: GENEVA 6 May 2024 - UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Trk on Monday warned that civilian deaths, suffering and destruction were set to increase beyond already unbearable levels following Israel's orders to Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah ahead of an anticipated new offensive. "Gazans continue to be hit with bombs, disease, and even famine. And today, they have been told that they must relocate yet again as Israeli military operations into Rafah scale up," the High Commissioner said. It runs contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which have the effective protection of civilians as their overriding concern.
1.title: Israel/Occupied Palestinian Territory: Rafah threat is inhumane, says UN Human Rights Chief [EN/AR]

SDG 1 - No Poverty.question: How is the lack of fuel impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza, according to UN officials?
SDG 1 - No Poverty.retrieved_answer:
According to UN officials, the lack of fuel is critically impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza [1][2][4].

For humanitarian operations, fuel is considered critical and could run out "tomorrow" [1][4]. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA), stated that humanitarians have approximately 30,000 litres of diesel available, while they normally use 200,000 litres daily [4]. The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off access to fuel, which affects the entry of critical relief items and restricts the movement of aid workers [1]. Scott Anderson from UNRWA noted that no fuel has entered the Gaza Strip, which is "disastrous for the humanitarian response" [2]. Aid agencies are nearly out of fuel [7], and stocks of critical supplies, including fuel, are being depleted hourly [8]. Priority for the remaining fuel is given to health, water, and communication, with some reserved for the secure movement of staff [4]. The UN aid coordination office (OCHA) is engaging with parties to resume the entry of goods, including fuel [8].

Regarding daily life, UN humanitarians have reported concerns over dwindling supplies of fuel and other basic necessities in Gaza [2]. The prioritization of fuel for health, water, and communication services indicates the impact on these essential aspects of daily life [4].

SDG 1 - No Poverty.question: How has the acceptance of a ceasefire proposal by Hamas and the subsequent Israeli response affected the humanitarian conditions in Rafah?
SDG 1 - No Poverty.retrieved_answer:
Hamas accepted a ceasefire proposal from Egypt and Qatar [1]. In response, Israel stated it would send a delegation to negotiate, but warned the proposal was far from "necessary requirements" [1]. The Israeli military also called on Palestinians in parts of eastern Rafah to "evacuate immediately" [1].

This sequence of events, including the "dashing ceasefire hopes" [2][3], was followed by the seizure of the Rafah crossing by Israeli forces on Tuesday [2][3][12]. Rafah is the main entry point for aid into Gaza [3][7][12]. As a result, no aid or fuel has entered the Gaza Strip [2][6][12], and aid agencies are nearly out of food and fuel [12]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out "tomorrow," and some food stocks might only last until the end of the week [6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel, affecting critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, Israeli evacuation orders [2][4] and attacks on Rafah [7] have forced tens of thousands [2] and over 100,000 people to flee [7]. These displaced individuals have nowhere safe to go [7][8], as designated evacuation sites like Al-Mawasi are overstretched, lack vital services, and are not safe [8][12]. People in these areas face impending famine, lack of shelter, spread of disease, and scarce healthcare availability [12]. Israeli ground operations and attacks in Rafah are escalating [7], bringing more death and displacement [4].

SDG 1 - No Poverty.question: What challenges are being faced by the humanitarian teams in Rafah, given the presence of over 1 million people, including 600,000 children?
SDG 1 - No Poverty.retrieved_answer: Humanitarian teams in Rafah, where well over 1 million people including 600,000 children remain, face significant challenges [5]. No aid, fuel, or critical relief items are entering Gaza, as the crossing area is an active war zone with ongoing military operations and bombardments [2][4][6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel and curtailed the movement of aid workers [4][6]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out, and some food stocks might only last to the end of the week [4]. Aid agencies are almost out of food and fuel, with stocks of critical supplies being depleted by the hour [6][10]. The situation remains extremely fluid amid active hostilities [10]. There are no safe zones in Gaza [3], and designated evacuation sites like Al Mawasi are unsuitable for hosting large numbers of displaced people, being overstretched and devoid of vital services, lacking capacity, safety assurances, and proper accommodation [6][9]. The safety of humanitarian workers is also a concern [7]. The lack of fuel has caused bakeries to stop working, leading to no bread, and has also affected water supply [8].

Those who evacuate must have enough time to do so, as well as a safe route and a safe place to go.Our teams are still in Rafah where well over 1 million people, including 600,000 children, remain. We are also extending our presence northwards to assist the families who have moved there.We remain committed to providing aid to people, regardless of where they are. The decisions that are made today and their consequences in human suffering will be remembered by the generation that follows us.

SDG 1 - No Poverty.question: How has the conflict in Gaza affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah?
SDG 1 - No Poverty.retrieved_answer:
The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
1.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe

13.context: So where should they go now?There is no safe place in Gaza!These exhausted, famished people, many of whom have been displaced many times already, have no good options. Other towns across Gaza, including Khan Younis, which is supposed to receive those who are being displaced from Rafah right now, have already been reduced to rubble, and remain under attack. These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.

SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.question: How is the lack of fuel impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza, according to UN officials?
SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.retrieved_answer:
According to UN officials, the lack of fuel is critically impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza [1][2][4].

For humanitarian operations, fuel is considered critical and could run out "tomorrow" [1][4]. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA), stated that humanitarians have approximately 30,000 litres of diesel available, while they normally use 200,000 litres daily [4]. The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off access to fuel, which affects the entry of critical relief items and restricts the movement of aid workers [1]. Scott Anderson from UNRWA noted that no fuel has entered the Gaza Strip, which is "disastrous for the humanitarian response" [2]. Aid agencies are nearly out of fuel [7], and stocks of critical supplies, including fuel, are being depleted hourly [8]. Priority for the remaining fuel is given to health, water, and communication, with some reserved for the secure movement of staff [4]. The UN aid coordination office (OCHA) is engaging with parties to resume the entry of goods, including fuel [8].

Regarding daily life, UN humanitarians have reported concerns over dwindling supplies of fuel and other basic necessities in Gaza [2]. The prioritization of fuel for health, water, and communication services indicates the impact on these essential aspects of daily life [4].

SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.question: How has the acceptance of a ceasefire proposal by Hamas and the subsequent Israeli response affected the humanitarian conditions in Rafah?
SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.retrieved_answer:
Hamas accepted a ceasefire proposal from Egypt and Qatar [1]. In response, Israel stated it would send a delegation to negotiate, but warned the proposal was far from "necessary requirements" [1]. The Israeli military also called on Palestinians in parts of eastern Rafah to "evacuate immediately" [1].

This sequence of events, including the "dashing ceasefire hopes" [2][3], was followed by the seizure of the Rafah crossing by Israeli forces on Tuesday [2][3][12]. Rafah is the main entry point for aid into Gaza [3][7][12]. As a result, no aid or fuel has entered the Gaza Strip [2][6][12], and aid agencies are nearly out of food and fuel [12]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out "tomorrow," and some food stocks might only last until the end of the week [6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel, affecting critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, Israeli evacuation orders [2][4] and attacks on Rafah [7] have forced tens of thousands [2] and over 100,000 people to flee [7]. These displaced individuals have nowhere safe to go [7][8], as designated evacuation sites like Al-Mawasi are overstretched, lack vital services, and are not safe [8][12]. People in these areas face impending famine, lack of shelter, spread of disease, and scarce healthcare availability [12]. Israeli ground operations and attacks in Rafah are escalating [7], bringing more death and displacement [4].

SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.retrieved_answer: The ongoing military operations and hostilities in Rafah are severely impacting humanitarian aid delivery [1][3][10]. No aid has been received, and the crossing area is an active war zone with continued bombardments [1]. The Rafah crossing, which serves as the main entry point for aid into Gaza and a lifeline for its people, was seized by Israeli forces on Tuesday [2][3]. Since last Sunday, no aid has entered Gaza by land [6]. This closure has severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [4]. Aid agencies are almost out of food and fuel in Gaza [6]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out soon, and some food stocks might only last to the end of the week [4]. SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.question: How has the conflict in Gaza affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah?
SDG 2 - Zero Hunger.retrieved_answer:
The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
1.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe

13.context: So where should they go now?There is no safe place in Gaza!These exhausted, famished people, many of whom have been displaced many times already, have no good options. Other towns across Gaza, including Khan Younis, which is supposed to receive those who are being displaced from Rafah right now, have already been reduced to rubble, and remain under attack. These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.

SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.question: What specific actions have the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) taken in response to rocket and mortar fire from Rafah, and how have these actions impacted the humanitarian situation in the area?
SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.retrieved_answer:
The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) have responded to rocket and mortar fire from Rafah by striking several sites in the area with aircraft [1]. These sites were used to fire rockets and mortars at Israel, including toward the Kerem Shalom Crossing [1]. Additionally, IDF troops engaged in close-quarters combat on the Gazan side of the Rafah crossing [1].

These Israeli operations and evacuation orders have significantly disrupted humanitarian activities in Gaza [2]. As a result of Israel's evacuation orders, Palestinians have evacuated Rafah [3], with roughly 50,000 people leaving the southern Gazan city in 48 hours [3], and over 150,000 people fleeing Rafah in recent days [4]. Around 300,000 people are now affected by these orders as Israel's attack on Rafah spreads and intensifies [4]. Displaced Palestinians have expressed fears following these orders [5], and many are sheltering in horrific conditions without adequate access to food, water, or other essentials [4]. The disruption to humanitarian operations in Rafah and the closure of Rafah Crossing will impact pre-existing needs in Rafah and across Gaza [2]. Extremely vulnerable people, including malnourished infants, the elderly, injured and sick patients, and people with severe disabilities, are among those ordered to move [4].

SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.question: How does the UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk view the Israeli orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, and what are the anticipated humanitarian consequences?
SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.retrieved_answer:
The UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk warned that Israel's orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, ahead of an anticipated new offensive, would cause civilian deaths, suffering, and destruction to increase beyond already unbearable levels [1]. He stated that Gazans are already being affected by bombs, disease, and famine, and are now being told to relocate again as Israeli military operations in Rafah escalate [1]. Türk views these orders as contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which prioritize the effective protection of civilians [1].

He also stated that Palestinians remaining in Rafah would continue to be at risk of death and injury from indiscriminate bombing, unlawful killing, or loss of access to food, water, and healthcare [2]. Türk emphasized that this situation "must not be allowed to happen" and that those who choose to disregard international humanitarian law and international human rights law must be held accountable [2].

"Gazans continue to be hit with bombs, disease, and even famine. And today, they have been told that they must relocate yet again as Israeli military operations into Rafah scale up," the High Commissioner said. It runs contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which have the effective protection of civilians as their overriding concern.

SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.question: How is the lack of fuel impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza, according to UN officials?
SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.retrieved_answer:
According to UN officials, the lack of fuel is critically impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza [1][2][4].

For humanitarian operations, fuel is considered critical and could run out "tomorrow" [1][4]. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA), stated that humanitarians have approximately 30,000 litres of diesel available, while they normally use 200,000 litres daily [4]. The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off access to fuel, which affects the entry of critical relief items and restricts the movement of aid workers [1]. Scott Anderson from UNRWA noted that no fuel has entered the Gaza Strip, which is "disastrous for the humanitarian response" [2]. Aid agencies are nearly out of fuel [7], and stocks of critical supplies, including fuel, are being depleted hourly [8]. Priority for the remaining fuel is given to health, water, and communication, with some reserved for the secure movement of staff [4]. The UN aid coordination office (OCHA) is engaging with parties to resume the entry of goods, including fuel [8].

Regarding daily life, UN humanitarians have reported concerns over dwindling supplies of fuel and other basic necessities in Gaza [2]. The prioritization of fuel for health, water, and communication services indicates the impact on these essential aspects of daily life [4].

SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.question: How has the acceptance of a ceasefire proposal by Hamas and the subsequent Israeli response affected the humanitarian conditions in Rafah?
SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.retrieved_answer:
Hamas accepted a ceasefire proposal from Egypt and Qatar [1]. In response, Israel stated it would send a delegation to negotiate, but warned the proposal was far from "necessary requirements" [1]. The Israeli military also called on Palestinians in parts of eastern Rafah to "evacuate immediately" [1].

This sequence of events, including the "dashing ceasefire hopes" [2][3], was followed by the seizure of the Rafah crossing by Israeli forces on Tuesday [2][3][12]. Rafah is the main entry point for aid into Gaza [3][7][12]. As a result, no aid or fuel has entered the Gaza Strip [2][6][12], and aid agencies are nearly out of food and fuel [12]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out "tomorrow," and some food stocks might only last until the end of the week [6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel, affecting critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, Israeli evacuation orders [2][4] and attacks on Rafah [7] have forced tens of thousands [2] and over 100,000 people to flee [7]. These displaced individuals have nowhere safe to go [7][8], as designated evacuation sites like Al-Mawasi are overstretched, lack vital services, and are not safe [8][12]. People in these areas face impending famine, lack of shelter, spread of disease, and scarce healthcare availability [12]. Israeli ground operations and attacks in Rafah are escalating [7], bringing more death and displacement [4].

SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.question: What challenges are being faced by the humanitarian teams in Rafah, given the presence of over 1 million people, including 600,000 children?
SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.retrieved_answer: Humanitarian teams in Rafah, where well over 1 million people including 600,000 children remain, face significant challenges [5]. No aid, fuel, or critical relief items are entering Gaza, as the crossing area is an active war zone with ongoing military operations and bombardments [2][4][6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel and curtailed the movement of aid workers [4][6]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out, and some food stocks might only last to the end of the week [4]. Aid agencies are almost out of food and fuel, with stocks of critical supplies being depleted by the hour [6][10]. The situation remains extremely fluid amid active hostilities [10]. There are no safe zones in Gaza [3], and designated evacuation sites like Al Mawasi are unsuitable for hosting large numbers of displaced people, being overstretched and devoid of vital services, lacking capacity, safety assurances, and proper accommodation [6][9]. The safety of humanitarian workers is also a concern [7]. The lack of fuel has caused bakeries to stop working, leading to no bread, and has also affected water supply [8].

SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.question: How has the conflict in Gaza affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah?
SDG 3 - Good Health and Well-being.retrieved_answer:
The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
1.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe

13.context: So where should they go now?There is no safe place in Gaza!These exhausted, famished people, many of whom have been displaced many times already, have no good options. Other towns across Gaza, including Khan Younis, which is supposed to receive those who are being displaced from Rafah right now, have already been reduced to rubble, and remain under attack. These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.
13.title: Comment by UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk on Gaza (12 May 2024)

4.context: title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe  content: Israel's disastrous invasion of Rafah, where more than one million Palestinians are sheltering for their lives, appears to be imminent. This morning the Israeli military has ordered 100,000 people in Eastern areas of the city to evacuate to areas adjacent to the already overcrowded coast where there is not enough shelter to receive them nor humanitarian supplies to sustain them.Once again, Israel's evacuation orders have sown fear and confusion among civilians who are desperate to reach protection. But as Medical Aid for Palestinians MAP and other humanitarian agencies have long made clear: there are no safe spaces in Gaza. Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones', killing displaced men, women and children.The evacuation order includes areas of both the Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which have been the key entry points for the limited aid allowed into Gaza for seven months.

SDG 6 - Clean Water and Sanitation.question: What challenges are being faced by the humanitarian teams in Rafah, given the presence of over 1 million people, including 600,000 children?
SDG 6 - Clean Water and Sanitation.retrieved_answer: Humanitarian teams in Rafah, where well over 1 million people including 600,000 children remain, face significant challenges [5]. No aid, fuel, or critical relief items are entering Gaza, as the crossing area is an active war zone with ongoing military operations and bombardments [2][4][6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel and curtailed the movement of aid workers [4][6]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out, and some food stocks might only last to the end of the week [4]. Aid agencies are almost out of food and fuel, with stocks of critical supplies being depleted by the hour [6][10]. The situation remains extremely fluid amid active hostilities [10]. There are no safe zones in Gaza [3], and designated evacuation sites like Al Mawasi are unsuitable for hosting large numbers of displaced people, being overstretched and devoid of vital services, lacking capacity, safety assurances, and proper accommodation [6][9]. The safety of humanitarian workers is also a concern [7]. The lack of fuel has caused bakeries to stop working, leading to no bread, and has also affected water supply [8].

We are also extending our presence northwards to assist the families who have moved there.We remain committed to providing aid to people, regardless of where they are. The decisions that are made today and their consequences in human suffering will be remembered by the generation that follows us.

SDG 6 - Clean Water and Sanitation.question: How has the conflict in Gaza affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah?
SDG 6 - Clean Water and Sanitation.retrieved_answer:
The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
1.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe

13.context: So where should they go now?There is no safe place in Gaza!These exhausted, famished people, many of whom have been displaced many times already, have no good options. Other towns across Gaza, including Khan Younis, which is supposed to receive those who are being displaced from Rafah right now, have already been reduced to rubble, and remain under attack. These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.
13.title: Comment by UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk on Gaza (12 May 2024)

This morning the Israeli military has ordered 100,000 people in Eastern areas of the city to evacuate to areas adjacent to the already overcrowded coast where there is not enough shelter to receive them nor humanitarian supplies to sustain them.Once again, Israel's evacuation orders have sown fear and confusion among civilians who are desperate to reach protection. But as Medical Aid for Palestinians MAP and other humanitarian agencies have long made clear: there are no safe spaces in Gaza. SDG 7 - Affordable and Clean Energy.question: How is the lack of fuel impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza, according to UN officials?
SDG 7 - Affordable and Clean Energy.retrieved_answer:
According to UN officials, the lack of fuel is critically impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza [1][2][4].

For humanitarian operations, fuel is considered critical and could run out "tomorrow" [1][4]. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA), stated that humanitarians have approximately 30,000 litres of diesel available, while they normally use 200,000 litres daily [4]. The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off access to fuel, which affects the entry of critical relief items and restricts the movement of aid workers [1]. Scott Anderson from UNRWA noted that no fuel has entered the Gaza Strip, which is "disastrous for the humanitarian response" [2]. Aid agencies are nearly out of fuel [7], and stocks of critical supplies, including fuel, are being depleted hourly [8]. Priority for the remaining fuel is given to health, water, and communication, with some reserved for the secure movement of staff [4]. The UN aid coordination office (OCHA) is engaging with parties to resume the entry of goods, including fuel [8].

Regarding daily life, UN humanitarians have reported concerns over dwindling supplies of fuel and other basic necessities in Gaza [2]. The prioritization of fuel for health, water, and communication services indicates the impact on these essential aspects of daily life [4].

And in case we lose accessibility, then we will be able to refer pregnant mothers, for instance, to field hospitals in Al Mawasi area as well as the Nasser Medical Complex," he said. SDG 10 - Reduced Inequalities.question: How does the UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk view the Israeli orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, and what are the anticipated humanitarian consequences?
SDG 10 - Reduced Inequalities.retrieved_answer:
The UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk warned that Israel's orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, ahead of an anticipated new offensive, would cause civilian deaths, suffering, and destruction to increase beyond already unbearable levels [1]. He stated that Gazans are already being affected by bombs, disease, and famine, and are now being told to relocate again as Israeli military operations in Rafah escalate [1]. Türk views these orders as contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which prioritize the effective protection of civilians [1].

He also stated that Palestinians remaining in Rafah would continue to be at risk of death and injury from indiscriminate bombing, unlawful killing, or loss of access to food, water, and healthcare [2]. Türk emphasized that this situation "must not be allowed to happen" and that those who choose to disregard international humanitarian law and international human rights law must be held accountable [2].

1.context: title: IsraelOccupied Palestinian Territory: Rafah threat is inhumane, says UN Human Rights Chief ENAR  content: GENEVA 6 May 2024 - UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Trk on Monday warned that civilian deaths, suffering and destruction were set to increase beyond already unbearable levels following Israel's orders to Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah ahead of an anticipated new offensive. "Gazans continue to be hit with bombs, disease, and even famine. And today, they have been told that they must relocate yet again as Israeli military operations into Rafah scale up," the High Commissioner said. It runs contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which have the effective protection of civilians as their overriding concern.
1.title: Israel/Occupied Palestinian Territory: Rafah threat is inhumane, says UN Human Rights Chief [EN/AR]

SDG 10 - Reduced Inequalities.question: How is the lack of fuel impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza, according to UN officials?
SDG 10 - Reduced Inequalities.retrieved_answer:
According to UN officials, the lack of fuel is critically impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza [1][2][4].

For humanitarian operations, fuel is considered critical and could run out "tomorrow" [1][4]. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA), stated that humanitarians have approximately 30,000 litres of diesel available, while they normally use 200,000 litres daily [4]. The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off access to fuel, which affects the entry of critical relief items and restricts the movement of aid workers [1]. Scott Anderson from UNRWA noted that no fuel has entered the Gaza Strip, which is "disastrous for the humanitarian response" [2]. Aid agencies are nearly out of fuel [7], and stocks of critical supplies, including fuel, are being depleted hourly [8]. Priority for the remaining fuel is given to health, water, and communication, with some reserved for the secure movement of staff [4]. The UN aid coordination office (OCHA) is engaging with parties to resume the entry of goods, including fuel [8].

Regarding daily life, UN humanitarians have reported concerns over dwindling supplies of fuel and other basic necessities in Gaza [2]. The prioritization of fuel for health, water, and communication services indicates the impact on these essential aspects of daily life [4].

SDG 10 - Reduced Inequalities.question: How has the conflict in Gaza affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah?
SDG 10 - Reduced Inequalities.retrieved_answer:
The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.

This sequence of events, including the "dashing ceasefire hopes" [2][3], was followed by the seizure of the Rafah crossing by Israeli forces on Tuesday [2][3][12]. These displaced individuals have nowhere safe to go [7][8], as designated evacuation sites like Al-Mawasi are overstretched, lack vital services, and are not safe [8][12]. SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.question: What specific actions have the Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) taken in response to rocket and mortar fire from Rafah, and how have these actions impacted the humanitarian situation in the area?
SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer:
The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) have responded to rocket and mortar fire from Rafah by striking several sites in the area with aircraft [1]. These sites were used to fire rockets and mortars at Israel, including toward the Kerem Shalom Crossing [1]. Additionally, IDF troops engaged in close-quarters combat on the Gazan side of the Rafah crossing [1].

These Israeli operations and evacuation orders have significantly disrupted humanitarian activities in Gaza [2]. As a result of Israel's evacuation orders, Palestinians have evacuated Rafah [3], with roughly 50,000 people leaving the southern Gazan city in 48 hours [3], and over 150,000 people fleeing Rafah in recent days [4]. Around 300,000 people are now affected by these orders as Israel's attack on Rafah spreads and intensifies [4]. Displaced Palestinians have expressed fears following these orders [5], and many are sheltering in horrific conditions without adequate access to food, water, or other essentials [4]. The disruption to humanitarian operations in Rafah and the closure of Rafah Crossing will impact pre-existing needs in Rafah and across Gaza [2]. Extremely vulnerable people, including malnourished infants, the elderly, injured and sick patients, and people with severe disabilities, are among those ordered to move [4].

SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.question: How does the UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk view the Israeli orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, and what are the anticipated humanitarian consequences?
SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer:
The UN Human Rights Chief Volker Türk warned that Israel's orders for Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah, ahead of an anticipated new offensive, would cause civilian deaths, suffering, and destruction to increase beyond already unbearable levels [1]. He stated that Gazans are already being affected by bombs, disease, and famine, and are now being told to relocate again as Israeli military operations in Rafah escalate [1]. Türk views these orders as contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which prioritize the effective protection of civilians [1].

He also stated that Palestinians remaining in Rafah would continue to be at risk of death and injury from indiscriminate bombing, unlawful killing, or loss of access to food, water, and healthcare [2]. Türk emphasized that this situation "must not be allowed to happen" and that those who choose to disregard international humanitarian law and international human rights law must be held accountable [2].

1.context: title: IsraelOccupied Palestinian Territory: Rafah threat is inhumane, says UN Human Rights Chief ENAR  content: GENEVA 6 May 2024 - UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Trk on Monday warned that civilian deaths, suffering and destruction were set to increase beyond already unbearable levels following Israel's orders to Palestinians to evacuate parts of Rafah ahead of an anticipated new offensive. "Gazans continue to be hit with bombs, disease, and even famine. And today, they have been told that they must relocate yet again as Israeli military operations into Rafah scale up," the High Commissioner said. It runs contrary to the basic principles of international humanitarian and human rights laws, which have the effective protection of civilians as their overriding concern.
1.title: Israel/Occupied Palestinian Territory: Rafah threat is inhumane, says UN Human Rights Chief [EN/AR]

SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.question: How is the lack of fuel impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza, according to UN officials?
SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer:
According to UN officials, the lack of fuel is critically impacting humanitarian operations and daily life in Gaza [1][2][4].

For humanitarian operations, fuel is considered critical and could run out "tomorrow" [1][4]. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office (OCHA), stated that humanitarians have approximately 30,000 litres of diesel available, while they normally use 200,000 litres daily [4]. The closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has cut off access to fuel, which affects the entry of critical relief items and restricts the movement of aid workers [1]. Scott Anderson from UNRWA noted that no fuel has entered the Gaza Strip, which is "disastrous for the humanitarian response" [2]. Aid agencies are nearly out of fuel [7], and stocks of critical supplies, including fuel, are being depleted hourly [8]. Priority for the remaining fuel is given to health, water, and communication, with some reserved for the secure movement of staff [4]. The UN aid coordination office (OCHA) is engaging with parties to resume the entry of goods, including fuel [8].

Regarding daily life, UN humanitarians have reported concerns over dwindling supplies of fuel and other basic necessities in Gaza [2]. The prioritization of fuel for health, water, and communication services indicates the impact on these essential aspects of daily life [4].

SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.question: How has the acceptance of a ceasefire proposal by Hamas and the subsequent Israeli response affected the humanitarian conditions in Rafah?
SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer:
Hamas accepted a ceasefire proposal from Egypt and Qatar [1]. In response, Israel stated it would send a delegation to negotiate, but warned the proposal was far from "necessary requirements" [1]. The Israeli military also called on Palestinians in parts of eastern Rafah to "evacuate immediately" [1].

This sequence of events, including the "dashing ceasefire hopes" [2][3], was followed by the seizure of the Rafah crossing by Israeli forces on Tuesday [2][3][12]. Rafah is the main entry point for aid into Gaza [3][7][12]. As a result, no aid or fuel has entered the Gaza Strip [2][6][12], and aid agencies are nearly out of food and fuel [12]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out "tomorrow," and some food stocks might only last until the end of the week [6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel, affecting critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, Israeli evacuation orders [2][4] and attacks on Rafah [7] have forced tens of thousands [2] and over 100,000 people to flee [7]. These displaced individuals have nowhere safe to go [7][8], as designated evacuation sites like Al-Mawasi are overstretched, lack vital services, and are not safe [8][12]. Additionally, more than a quarter of humanitarian missions to northern Gaza in April were impeded by Israeli authorities, and 10 percent were denied [2]. The situation remains extremely fluid amid active hostilities [10].

SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer: Humanitarian teams in Rafah, where well over 1 million people including 600,000 children remain, face significant challenges [5]. No aid, fuel, or critical relief items are entering Gaza, as the crossing area is an active war zone with ongoing military operations and bombardments [2][4][6]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has severed access to fuel and curtailed the movement of aid workers [4][6]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out, and some food stocks might only last to the end of the week [4]. Aid agencies are almost out of food and fuel, with stocks of critical supplies being depleted by the hour [6][10]. The situation remains extremely fluid amid active hostilities [10]. There are no safe zones in Gaza [3], and designated evacuation sites like Al Mawasi are unsuitable for hosting large numbers of displaced people, being overstretched and devoid of vital services, lacking capacity, safety assurances, and proper accommodation [6][9]. The safety of humanitarian workers is also a concern [7]. The lack of fuel has caused bakeries to stop working, leading to no bread, and has also affected water supply [8].

SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.question: How has the conflict in Gaza affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah?
SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer:
The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
1.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe

13.context: So where should they go now?There is no safe place in Gaza!These exhausted, famished people, many of whom have been displaced many times already, have no good options. Other towns across Gaza, including Khan Younis, which is supposed to receive those who are being displaced from Rafah right now, have already been reduced to rubble, and remain under attack. These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.
13.title: Comment by UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk on Gaza (12 May 2024)

SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.question: . What are the main obstacles to achieving a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas, according to the provided text?
SDG 16 - Peace, Justice and Strong Insti.retrieved_answer:
The main obstacles to achieving a ceasefire between Israel and Hamas include Israel's rejection of proposals that do not meet its "core demands" [5] and its stated "red line" against a permanent end to hostilities [4]. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has said he will not accept an end to the war [4] and that Israel has "no choice" but to destroy Hamas [19], which is his goal [8]. For Hamas, releasing hostages without an assurance of a permanent ceasefire is not acceptable [8].

Hamas stated that Israel's rejection of the mediators' proposal returned things to "the first square" [3], and a senior Hamas official said "occupation Israelis turned against the mediators' proposal" [21]. Hamas had agreed to a framework proposal that diverged from the one Israel had helped craft [4].

Additionally, Israel's renewed military activity in Rafah [1], its plan for an all-out assault on Rafah [3], and the seizure of the Rafah crossing by Israeli forces have dashed ceasefire hopes [11]. The UN Secretary-General has called on both Hamas and Israel "to show political courage" to secure a ceasefire [1].

1.context: title: Hamas says Gaza ceasefire efforts are back at square one  content: Israel's plan for an all-out assault on Rafah has ignited one of the biggest rifts in generations with its main ally. Israel said the Hamas proposal contained elements it cannot accept. "Israel's rejection of the mediators' proposal through the amendments it made returned things to the first square," Hamas said in Friday's statement. "In the light of Israel Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's behaviour and rejection of the mediators' document and the attack on Rafah and the occupation of the crossing, the leadership of the movement will hold consultations with the brotherly leaders of the Palestinian factions to review our negotiation strategy.

"It incudes a permanent end to hostilities, which is a red line for Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu," the senior US official said. "This is not the same position," the senior Israeli official said.The senior Israeli official said the Israeli government was sending a working-level delegation to meet with Egyptian and Qatari mediators in order to better understand the latest proposal and determine whether a deal can be forged.

The conflict in Gaza has severely affected the ability of humanitarian teams to operate and provide aid in Rafah. There is a dire shortage of fuel, which hinders everything from the movement and distribution of food to the operation of hospitals, emergency services, sewage treatment, and telecommunications [1]. Fuel critical for humanitarian operations could run out [6].

Aid flow through the Rafah crossing has halted, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [13]. The Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which were key entry points for limited aid, have been disrupted [2][4]. Israeli forces seized the Rafah crossing [3] and blocked the passage for people and humanitarian aid [5]. No fuel or aid has entered the Gaza Strip, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. The closure of the Rafah crossing has also severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers [6].

Furthermore, there are no safe places in Gaza [1][2][5], as Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones' [2][5]. Other towns, like Khan Younis, have been reduced to rubble and remain under attack, making them unsafe [1]. Evacuation orders have uprooted tens of thousands of people in Rafah, sowing fear and confusion among civilians [2][3]. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted [4], and the closure of crossings will lead to increased hunger and scarcity [8].

1.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
1.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe

13.context: So where should they go now?There is no safe place in Gaza!These exhausted, famished people, many of whom have been displaced many times already, have no good options. Other towns across Gaza, including Khan Younis, which is supposed to receive those who are being displaced from Rafah right now, have already been reduced to rubble, and remain under attack. These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.
13.title: Comment by UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk on Gaza (12 May 2024)

2.context: "We have been ensuring that the hospital is fully occupied. And in case we lose accessibility, then we will be able to refer pregnant mothers, for instance, to field hospitals in Al Mawasi area as well as the Nasser Medical Complex," he said. Fuel running outMeanwhile, fuel critical for humanitarian operations in Gaza could run out "tomorrow" and some food stocks might only last to the end of the week, a senior UN aid official in the region said on Tuesday. Andrea de Domenico, head of the UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, in the occupied Palestinian territories, said the closure of the Rafah crossing with Egypt has severed access to fuel, affecting the entry of critical relief items and curtailing the movement of aid workers.
2.title: Patients in Rafah ‘afraid to seek services’, WHO reports

Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called safe zones', killing displaced people. Any claims from Israel that civilians can be safely relocated have no credibility.The failure of our leaders to back words with meaningful action is glaring.
3.title: Joint NGO Statement on Gaza

4.context: title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe  content: Israel's disastrous invasion of Rafah, where more than one million Palestinians are sheltering for their lives, appears to be imminent. This morning the Israeli military has ordered 100,000 people in Eastern areas of the city to evacuate to areas adjacent to the already overcrowded coast where there is not enough shelter to receive them nor humanitarian supplies to sustain them.Once again, Israel's evacuation orders have sown fear and confusion among civilians who are desperate to reach protection. But as Medical Aid for Palestinians MAP and other humanitarian agencies have long made clear: there are no safe spaces in Gaza. Israel has repeatedly attacked so-called 'safe zones', killing displaced men, women and children.The evacuation order includes areas of both the Rafah and Karem Abu Salem crossings, which have been the key entry points for the limited aid allowed into Gaza for seven months.
4.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe
